profileText: A Representative from Pennsylvania; born in Philadelphia, Pa., May 16, 1773; attended the common schools; completed the medical course at the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia in 1793 and continued studies in Europe, where he attended schools in Edinburgh, Gottingen, and Paris; returned to Philadelphia and devoted himself to chemistry and mineralogy; elected as a member of the American Philosophical Society in 1797; elected as a Republican to the Eleventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Benjamin Say; reelected to the Twelfth and Thirteenth Congresses and served from October 10, 1809, to March 3, 1815; chairman, Committee on Revisal and Unfinished Business (Twelfth Congress); elected to the Fifteenth Congress (March 4, 1817-March 3, 1819); visited Europe 1819-1821 and again in 1824 and settled in Paris, France, where he died May 2, 1825; interment in PÃ¨re Lachaise Cemetery, Paris, France.

note.content: One of three elected to represent 3rd district.
Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Benjamin Say, and took his seat November 27, 1809.
One of three elected to represent 1st district.
One of four elected to represent 1st district.
One of four elected to represent 1st district.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Seybert, Adam. An inaugural dissertation: being an attempt to disprove the doctrine of the putrefaction of the blood of living animals. Philadelphia: Printed by T. Dobson, at the Stonehouse, no. 41, South Second-Street, 1743.
------. An oration, delivered on the 19 of May, 1809, at the meeting of the manufacturers and mechanics of the City of Philadelphia. Philadelphia: Printed by Order of the Committee, 1809.

------. Statistical annals; embracing views of the population, commerce, navigation, fisheries, public lands, post-office establishment, revenues, mint, military & naval establishments, expenditures, public debt, and sinking fund, of the United States of America. Philadelphia: Published by Thomas Dobson & Son, at the Stone House, no.41, South Second, between Market and Chestnut Street. William Fry, printer, 1818. Reprint, New York: A. M. Kelley, 1970.

researchRecord.name: 1810, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A commonplace book of Adam Seybert with writings on various topics.

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, ca. 1668-1983, 25 linear feet.
1813, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Adam Seybert to to Messrs. Johnson and Warner, written on December 14, 1813. In the letter, Seybert answers a number of questions (not present) on Pennsylvania government.

researchRecord.name: 1819, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Adam Seybert to J.H. Tiffany written on February 25, 1819. In the letter, Seybert answers a number of questions (not present) on the history and government of Pennsylvania.

researchRecord.name: In the Thomas Cooper Letters to Alexander James Dallas, 1800-1816, 53 items.
